abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for this project are as
            follows: The project outcome is satisfactory, project
            sustainability is highly likely, the institutional
            development impact is substantial, and the overall
            performance of the World Bank and the Borrower is
            satisfactory. A number of key lessons, both positive and
            negative, were learned during the implementation of the
            project which were summarized as follows: The
            Government's strong commitment to reforms and
            continuous support to seed sector commercialization effort
            have been the foundation of the project design and the
            pillar for project implementation. Close cooperation between
            government agencies at various levels played a key role in
            project implementation. Functional institutional arrangement
            and close involvement of technical specialists also
            contributed to the satisfactory project implementation. The
            Project's simple objective and focused design were
            considered key elements for satisfactory project
            implementation. Procurement issues including one
            mis-procurement declared by the World Bank had negative
            effects on project implementation. This was derived mainly
            from (i) project staff's insufficient knowledge of
            World Bank procurement policies and procedures and contract
            management and (ii) inadequate support from the World Bank
            especially in the early years of project implementation.
            Staff instability and discontinuity was a major problem for
            some project management offices where project trained staff
            were posted to other duties outside the project. In projects
            with an important training component, an agreement might be
            necessary among concerned parties that staff included in the
            project training program should return to their original or
            related posts to continue the staff's service for at
            least a specified period with minimum predefined exceptions.
            Failure to have such a requirement runs the risk of either
            (i) less than optimum selection of candidates, or (ii)
            wastage of the training investment through the loss of the
            trained staff to other employment, or both.
